Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: AYES PAIRS
text: You will address your remarks through the chair; do not address them to members across the chamber.  am doing that via you. I shall not comment on it; others can hear it. As the current Prime Minister said in 1986, just 12 years ago, his belief was-and the policy of those opposite was-that Medicare has been an unmitigated disaster, that it needs radical surgery and bulk-billing will be abolished. I want to tell those opposite this: you can pretend to yourselves-like the member for Bowman (Mrs West) said-that those who turned up at her Medicare rally were Labor hacks. To hear this mythology again coming from the other side of the House shows they do not understand. My friend the member for Paterson has come back. Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: AYES PAIRS
text: Mitchell-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business) (5.16 p.m.)During the debate the shadow minister raised a couple of questions which I wish to respond to briefly. I think that his questions really revolved around the certainty of protectionto make sure that there is the same protection for individuals and for people who might be using hospital services-and around the prospect of states making further or new charges. Those health care agreement principles are the five year principles; they are embodied in the five year agreement. Mr Lee-The second question was: have you had legal advice?

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: AYES PAIRS

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Mr Forrest)Order! It being after 5.30 p.m., I propose the question: That the House do now adjourn. Medicare Office: Belmont  p.m.)-This afternoon I want to draw attention to action by the Federal Airports Corporation to massively increase landing charges at Sydney airport for regional airline operators. The effect of that in the Hunter area would be to increase, for instance, charges per passenger for Impulse Airlines from $6 per passenger up to $28 per passenger by the year 2000, and similarly for aircraft operating out of Belmont for Aeropelican the total effect of the increase would be to increase by 332 per cent the cost of the landing charges they would be eligible to pay-in other words, from $135,000 to $450,000 per year. What that scale of charges constitutes is effectively a strategy to lock regional airline operators out of Sydney airport. The people I represent in the Hunter and on the Central Coast are not going to accept second-class treatment in respect of airline services from this government. We, as non-metropolitan Australians, are as much entitled to easy air access to the international and national airline network as. are metropolitan Australians in the Sydney region. Access to that service is critically important for family reasons, for the conduct of business, for industry reasons, for access of our customers to the Hunter region to visit and see the products we sell and to inspect the services we provide, and it is of extreme importance for the growth of our tourism industry. I call on the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Vaile) to direct the Minister for Finance and Administration (Mr Fahey), who has now joined in the attack on regional airlines in his newsletter, to cease his attacks on regional airlines and regional airline passengers. I refer to the newsletter put out by the Minister for Finance and Administration in his own electorate entitled 'Airport News for Macarthur', March 1998. A paragraph in that reads: If regional and other smaller flights such as thesereferring to regional and non-scheduled flightsAviation can be. diverted to another airport, perhaps Bankstown, It may be that a second airport is not required for decades to come-it's a possibility that would require detailed investigation. That is a fallacy from beginning to end. Bankstown is not an alternate airport in terms of service and accessibility for regional airlines. The linkage for regional airlines is into the national airline network and into the international airline network in both its inbound and outbound services. I also call on the Minister for Transport and Regional Development to direct the Federal Airports Corporation-he has that power under the act-to abandon its proposed increased charges. That matter would be most detrimental to the people I represent, and particularly to the people of the Hunter. I make one last plea in these few minutes to the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge). I have spoken in this House several times already in support of the retention of Belmont Medicare office. I have written to the minister this week and I have spoken to the minister this week. It is scheduled to be closed tomorrow. I want to be able to go back to Belmont tomorrow and have a celebration for the people of Belmont. Not for me-it does not matter to me; it is not me that is affected-but the people in the families who need immediate cash payments after they have been to the doctor. I want him to reverse that decision. I cling to that hope. I am waiting on a response from him. I have indicated to him that there would certainly be recognition of that reversal of opinion. Sure, it would take some courage, but it can be done and in this case it ought to be done. Almost 14,000 signatures have appeared on petitions I have presented to this parliament in support of the retention of that office. That ought to be a clear indication to everybody how important that service is to Australians. They want their Medicare service. They want access to reasonable health care, to quality health care, and they want access to immediate cash payments after they have -, been to the doctor and paid their bills. So I appeal to the minister again, remembering also that we have seen from this government in its commitment to health care $800 million stripped from the public hospital system. We have seen a situation where $1.7 billion has been pumped into private health funds when less than one in three people in this country believe that private health funds are value for money. (Time expired) Aged Care

Speaker: Mr BOB BALDWIN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Earlier this week I received a letter in my office from 'a Mr Kel Snowden of Salamander Bay. It was a copy of a letter addressed to Jenny Macklin MP. You see, Ms Macklin is coming to my electorate tomorrow! and we do welcome her there. The only thing we hope is that she can continue to tell the truth while she is there.

Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: The honourable member will not reflect on other members. I think you might withdraw the inference.

Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I withdraw that. The letter says: I'm sorry I will not be able to attend your Public Meeting in Nelson Bay on 27th inst. owing to a prior engagement. However, in your position as Shadow Minister I wish to bring to your notice and consideration on .the following matters which greatly coricem me as I'm just a couple of months off my 92nd birthday. Now these are ,things in the Health System.I wish to forcibly bring to your notice, especially your purpose and the purpose of the Party of which you are a member are determined to castigate and denigrate the Howard Govt. Speaker: Mr JENKINS
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: With the announcement of the Prime Minister Howard) that the government is privatise Telstra so as to fund an election war chest, it is likely that the House will witness more of the unfettered support speeches for the sale of the kind given by the honourable member for Boothby (Dr Southcott) in the adjournment debate on Monday night. It was an adjournment speech in which he went siderations through the ideology of the sale as he saw it, citing examples of what had happened in account. Cuba and Albania. I would suggest that the only people who really have a policy driven by ideology are those who sit on the governtee's ment benches. They are pursuing their love for the free market and privatisation to the detriment of all else. Telstra is a classic example of this. If we look at Labor's policy on Telstra, decided at the national conference in Hobart earlier this year, we recognise the enormous role that Telstra plays in the national econ Mr omy and in the community generally. If we look at some of the polling since the Prime Minister's announcement, we see that the preselected, majority of the public also think that way. poll in the West Australian on 24 March shows 60 per cent against the sale. The in the Herald Sun in Melbourne on 19 March showed 58 per cent against. This week's Bulletin shows that 62 per cent totally disagree with the coalition's Telstra sell-off. What was very instructive about that was that 63 per cent of non-Telstra shareholders and on the the majority of Telstra shareholders-55 per to be cent-are against the sale. We have the likes of the member for Boothby coming in and quoting figures on so economics that he has been given by senior members of the government. I perhaps would me suggest to him that he might look at articles to be like that which appeared in the Financial Review of last Thursday where John Quiggin, out who I believe is somebody who makes a lot sense when he writes articles about current dead affairs, indicated that some of the sums that are being put forward are out of order. He suggests that the saving that might be achieved by the sale based on the interest Telstra rates that prevail is about $2.5 billion, not $4 billion that has been suggested by senior members of the government or $3 billion as (Mr suggested by the honourable member for to fully Boothby on Monday night. John Quiggin goes on to say that when you take into account the dividend and the value of return investments to Telstra, five years after a full sale, the effect of the sale of Telstra will be negative. These are the conthat in a proper full debate about the full sell-off of Telstra should be taken into I also want to raise some of the information that was highlighted in the Senate commitreport of 1996 entitled Telstra-to sell or not to sell, where at appendix 8 they listed the cross-subsidies in each federal electorate. It makes very instructive reading. In the electorate of Paterson in New South as Wales-the honourable member for Paterson (Mr Bob Baldwin) has now left the chamber-the cross-subsidies were $1.136 million. Speaker, I understand that the National Party is looking for another candidate for the electorate of Parkes. That candidate, when will have to explain the effect on A the cross-subsidy there in Parkes of $15.215 million. In my state of Victoria the honourpoll able member for MCEwen (Mrs Bailey) will have to explain what effect the full sale of Telstra will have on the $2.284 million crosssubsidy. In the state of Queensland the person who will be preselected to take the place of the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor)-a very fine member of this Housewill have to explain what is going to happen to the $0.5 million of cross-subsidy. The honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Kauer) will have to explain $10.7 million worth of cross-subsidy. What will happen to that? No won<;ier the honourable member for Kennedy is so concerned about the sale. And the list goes on. These are the things that those people in rural Australia are very concerned about. There is no guarantee that, under a fully privatised Telstra, the type of cross-subsidies that enable services to be put into the rural areas will continue. Even under the partially privatised Telstra very important services apply in the rural sector have already been done away with. The employment consequences will also be seen. Twenty-four thousand was the figure suggested in the Mercury report. Many of those positions were in rural Australia. What will honourable members on the other side be saying about those issues? (Time expired) Asian Financial Crisis

Speaker: Mr TAYLOR
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Groom) (5.46 p.m.)Earlier today we debated in this place a piece of relatively minor amending legislation in relation to the International Monetary Fund and arrangements which we want to put into place. I and a number of my colleagues were disappointed that we were not able to contribute to that debate. Whilst the content of the legislation was. relatively minor, underpinning it was a very serious problem having not only domestic implications for Australia but also international ramifications. The Asian financial crisis, which started currency markets in South-East Asia and spread to other markets, first undermined confidence and then faith in the certainty of continued high growth in the region-the so called East Asian miracle-and the ensuing economic downturn has raised very serious questions about the foundations of that growth, the soundness of the region's financial sectors, the role of government in directing investment and lending and even the appropriateness of Asian values in the context of free market orthodoxy. It has also presented the region's economies with a number of interrelated challenges: implementing the financial sector reforms needed to attract foreign capital back into the region, establishing governance practices which will improve transparency and accountability and developing growth strategies which are both sustainable and inclusive. As a country Australia can be proud of what it has achieved, particularly over the last two years, economically at the domestic level. I listened to a number of very good speeches on that legislation from the other side of the House, in particular the speech from the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis). I do not agree with him that the IMF that is the total negative factor in this whole equation. I certainly do not agree with him that, had this government not taken the measures that it has taken domestically, we would not be insulated to the extent that we clearly are, albeit with the potential for trade figures in due course to be adversely affected-hopefully, not to the degree that some in the opposition might want to see. This is not just an East Asian problem. It has economic, political and strategic dimensions. I agree particularly with an article I read in the Far Eastern Economic Review of 12 February this year. It said: What the region needs is to put in place a political system that places values on accountability and transparency, that controls corruption and sets up an administrative and regulatory system that is suited to the age of globalisation. If we do not watch it, there is also a global potential that none of us would want in relation to the Asian financial problems that exist at the moment. It is in everybody's in interest-in this country and in other countries-to acknowledge that. In particular, the IMF package will not happen to the extent that it should unless the US Congress agrees to play its part in the assistance packages. When I was there six or eight weeks ago there was a very mixed reaction. I hope that when it does come to a vote later on this month or in April, congressmen and senators on both sides will see exactly what this is all about. It is a problem that we and they have to come to grips with, otherwise we will see this serious problem move into Japan-as undoubtedly it already has, to a limited extent-across the Pacific and we will have total deflation right around the world if we do not watch it. None of us want that. I just hope that the US Congress clears what is a reasonable package and that that will happen fairly soon. Carrum Downs

Speaker: Mr WILTON
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I rise to draw the federal parliament's attention to the plight of Carrum Downs, which is a very important part of my electorate of Isaacs. Like other regions, Carrum Downs began as a rural hamlet. Since 1978 the population has grown substantially. According to the 1996 census, Carrum Downs was the fastest growing urban centre in Victoria between 1991 and 1996. That made it the 10th fastest growing area in Australia at that time-growing at an astounding rate of 82.6 per cent during that period. Sadly, however, many of the government services it receives have been left one step behind. In Carrum Downs, 31.2 per cent of the population are under IS-the national average is 21.6 per cent-but there are very few services for these kids. It is not just that is no youth centre, no local cinema and no easily accessible public transport that young children can access but many other things. Indeed, with little local employment opportunities it is very difficult for young kids in Carrum Downs to get on the job training at a young age to equip them with the skills that they know they will need in their later adult working lives. Of course, the government also seeks to penalise Carrum. Downs families if their children cannot get jobs. The common youth allowance will no doubt hurt many Carrum Downs families. Those with an unemployed teenager may face having to come up with an extra $178 per fortntght to support their young unemployed adult. A family that earns $23,400 per year will face a cut in the amount of money their young adult receives from the government also---a further slight on families. The government's youth allowance will force families earning below average incomes to financially support their young unemployed adults. The majority of families in Carrum Downs are paying off a mortgage and also struggling to educate their young children. Now they will also have to pay food, clothing and transport costs for their young job seekers as well. In terms of child care, 13.5 per cent of the local population are aged five years and under, so child care is a big issue in Carrum Downs. Of course, I am speaking on behalf of families in that area when I say that the government's child-care cuts are really hurting them. This government has taken some $820 million out of child care in its last two budgets and it has shown, once again, that it has no regard for the provision of quality child care. This is an issue that I will definitely pursue across the area of Carrum Downs. I will certainly produce a survey for both parents and child-care centres to complete so that I can present the concerns about these government cutbacks direct to the federal parliament. Older Carrum Downs residents need the support and assistance of their government. They, of course, have paid taxes all their lives and many of them fought during World War there ll. They have worked hard to raise families and have made many great sacrifices. But from 1 March many older Australians, including many in Carrum Downs, needing to enter a nursing home will face· an extra daily fee. These nursing home fees will amount to up to $64 a day. The money does not go to the nursing home itself; it goes to the government and is nothing more, in that sense, than a disguised new tax. It comes on top of a new annual fee for nursing home care of up to $4,380 and must be paid by anyone with assets of more than $44,400. Those with between $22,500 and $44,399 in assets will pay a lesser charge. If these assets include the family home, most will have to pay the full amount and possibly sell their home to do it. Older Australians have already had to suffer the abolition of the Commonwealth dental scheme, an increase in home and community care charges, restrictions on hearing services and, most recently, an increase in the cost of essential medicines. It is just not fair and it certainly hurts both working and retired men and women struggling in areas like Carrum Downs. But Labor, Mr Speaker, you will be pleased to know, has promised to abolish both new fees and, what is more, Kim Beazley has guaranteed that Labor will put back the $500 million John Howard has cut from aged care. There is no doubt that the community of Carrum Downs needs more government assistance to ensure that its expanding community prospers and develops into an even better place to live. The people of Carrum Downs deserve better than constant government cuts and I will do all I can to ensure that those cuts are remedied for the Carrum Downs area. (Time expired) Bringing Them Home

Speaker: Mr TONY SMITH
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Francis Bacon once said: That which is past is gone and irrevocable, and wise men have enough to do with things present and to come. Therefore. they do but trifle with themselves that labour in past matters. Last year we had the rather unedifying spectacle of members of the Labor Party, night after night in the adjournment debate, reading extracts from the Bringing Them Home document. I am not suggesting that those members who were reading this document did not do it seriously. However, I believe they were also probably instructed to try to deliver a political blow to those who sit on this side of the House. The simple message was: we care but you do not; we have the high moral ground but you do not. I was not impressed with the Bringing Them Home document. I was not impressed by the bleeding heart publicity surrounding the inquiry itself, all directed at pointing the finger at us as somehow being responsible for deeds done in the past. But, more than that, the tenor of the report was rhetorical and in parts quite poorly written. It suffered no criticism, notwithstanding the comments of former judge Sir Ronald Wilson, who was the author of the report along with others, when he said: Who needed corroboration when you saw tears running down the cheeks? I must say the judge needs a lesson in what it is like in the courts at first instance. I could take him around the District Court in Brisbane on any weekday and he would find half of all the complainants with tears running down their cheeks who were later found by juries to be absolute liars. That is a lesson that the judge, who I believe never practised at first instance in criminal courts, would need to understand. Recently Canada fell into that trap. It made an apology after much cajoling by the indigenous industry and straight away promised additional funding. However, four of the five indigenous leaders who were handed the scrolls of the reconciliation statement dismissed the apology as too weak and the funding as inadequate. The paradox is that those calling for apologies or reconciliation seem active in maintaining a political standoff which suits their position of influence. The black American commentator Thomas Sal has noted that these people have little incentive to bring about genuine reconciliation as their position usually depends on maintaining a climate of division. Les Carlyon recently wrote that the apology was a: ... then and now thing. You apologise for then but not for now. Tony Blair apologised for the Irish potato famine of the 1840s but not for Margaret Thatcher. President Clinton apologised for slavery but not for the CIA's roguery in Latin America or even for Michael Jackson. Mr Tanner-What's Michael Jackson got to do. with it?

Mr Beazley to move That this House: (1) notes the publication of the National Accounts for the December quarter of 1997 which show that economic growth, as measured by GDP(A), was (a) 2.8 per cent in calendar year 1997 and (b) 3.6 per cent in the year to the December quarter of 1997; (2) notes that the performance of the Australian economy under the Howard Coalition Government compares unfavourably with growth under the previous Labor Government when (a) economic growth in the year to March 1996 was 4.7 per cent and (b) the average annual growth over the Labor Government's last term, March 1993 to March 1996, was 4.4 per cent; (3) notes that economic growth over 1997 was (a) 0.9 percentage points lower than calendar year 1996 and (b) the lowest level of economic growth for five calendar years; and (4) notes that the Howard Government's massive cuts to employment and industry programs in its two slash and bum budgets and NA its constant undermining of business and consumer confidence have directly contributed to the Australian economy's poor growth performance compared with the last term of the Labor Government. (2) Are there exceptions to the requirement referred to in part (1); if so, what are the exceptions. (3) How many doctors referred to in part (1) have (a) passed examination or (b) been excepted from examination. (4) How many overseas trained doctors entered Australia in 1996-97. (5) From which countries did they originate. (6) How many doctors from each country referred to in part (5) (a) entered Australia, (b) passed examination, (c) were excepted from examination and (d) applied from within Australia to extend their residency. Mr Rud,dock-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) Foreign doctors entering Australia on temporary visas are not required to pass the Australian Medical Council examination. Temporary resident doctors are, however, required to obtain registration with the relevant State or Territory Medical Boards before practicing in Australia. (2) There are no exceptions to the requirement referred to in the response to question (1). (3) See response to questions (1) and (2). (4) 898 doctors on temporary resident visas entered Australia in 1996-97. (5) The temporary resident doctors were from the following countries: Bangladesh, Belgium, Canada, Denmark, France, Germany, Greece, India, Ireland, Israel, Italy, Jordan, Malaysia, Myanmar, Namibia, Netherlands, Niger, Nigeria, Pakistan, Papua New Guinea, Philippines, Poland, Singapore, South Africa, Spain, Sri Lanka, St Lucia, Switzerland, Tonga, United Kingdom, United States of America and Vanuatu. Misuse of Medicare (Question No. 2675) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 2 March 1998: (1) Has he consulted the Minister for Health to determine how many non-residents or non-citizens have undergone surgical procedures uSIng Medicare; if so. what are the details; if not, why not. (2) What statistics are available on the misuse of Medicare referred to in part (1). (3) Do the statistics indicate the extent to which the misuse relates to medical conditions which existed before arrival in Australia. (4) Is he able to say how many persons referred to in part (1) returned voluntarily to their country of nationality after treatment. Mr Ruddock-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) to (4) I have asked my Department to consult with the Department of Health and Family Services (DHFS) on this matter. DHFS advises that nonresidents do not have access to the Medicare arrangements except to the extent to which access is provided under the terms of a Reciprocal Health Care Arrangement. The Health Insurance Act 1973 (HIA) defines which people are eligible for Medicare. Eligibility for Medicare is generally restricted to an 'Australian resident' as defined in Section 3 of the HIA and the person must reside in Australia. Therefore: generally, non-residents do not qualify for, nor receive access to, Medicare benefits. No data distinguishes between access to Medicare by non-citizens as opposed to citizens, as once a person meets the definition of Australian resident in the HIA, they are an eligible person and may use Medicare. Data regarding numbers of persons accessing surgical procedures in public hospitals are held by the States and Territories. Residence Order Enforcement (Question No. 2702) Mr Lindsay asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 2 March 1998: (1) How may residence/residence orders enforcing a minimum stay with either parent of 40 per cent has the Family Court issued since the Family Law Reform Act 1995 was implemented. (2) What percentage does the figure referred to in part (1) constitute of the total number of Family Court orders issued in the same period. (3) How many residence/residence orders have been issued since the B&B case was concluded. Mr Williams-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) The Family Court has advised me that the number of residence/residence orders enforcing a minimum stay with either parent of 40 percent, issued by the Family Court of Australia since 11 June 1996 (when the Family Law Reform Act was proclaimed) is not readily available, as information about the proportional split is not entered onto the Court's case management system. However, the Family Court has further advised me that it is estimated that the total number of all residence/residence orders (including consent and other court orders) made in the period from 1 July 1996 to 28 February 1998 was 1,280. (2) The Family Court has advised me that the total number of orders made in respect of children (including residence, contact and specific issues orders) made in the Family Court of Australia during the period from 1 July 1996 to 28 February 1998 was 76,750. The Family Court has further advised me that residence/residence orders therefore constituted approximately 1.7% of the total orders relating to children made during this period. (3) The Family Court has advised me that the total number of residence/residence orders (including consent and other court orders) made in the Family Court of Australia since judgment in the B&B case was handed down, on 9 July 1997, to 28 February 1998 is estimated to be 470. Indigenous Cultural Property: Repatriated to Australia (Question No. 2719) Mr Latham asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, upon notice, on 5 March 1998: (1) Can the Minister say (a) what items of indigenous cultural property have been repatriated to Australia since 1988 and (b) when, whence and in what circumstances they were repatriated. (2) What decisions and recommendations were made concerning indigenous cultural property and archives at the 13th meeting of the Cultural Ministers Council in Adelaide on 27 February 1998. (3) When and where will the 13th meeting of the council be held. Mr Warwick Smith-The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: (1) The return of indigenous cultural property from overseas falls within the portfolio responsibilities of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. (2) At the 13th meeting of the Cultural Ministers Council held in Adelaide on 27 February 1998, members endorsed the approach set out in the strategic plan for the repatriation of indigenous ancestral remains and secret/sacred objects by 2001. The objectives of the strategic plan are to: identify where possible, the origins of all ancestral remains and secret/sacred objects held in museums, with records placed in national databases; notify all affected indigenous communities; and negotiate with museums and communities concerning repatriation when and where requested. Ministers undertook to consider funding for the implementation of the strategy in accordance with the agreed CMC formula and agreed to report back on deliberations by 30 June 1998 or at the next Standing Committee meeting, whichever is the sooner. (3) The 14th meeting of the Cultural Ministers Council will be held in June 1998, in New South Wales. Harbour Masters: Powers (Question No. 2738) Mr Campbell asked the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 10 March 1998: Are harbour masters or officers in his Department empowered under federal legislation to prevent a ship from sailing if they believe that ship's master or crew are suffering from fatigue. Mr Reith-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: Harbour masters' authority is vested in them through State legislation and the honourable member should approach the relevant State authorities on this issue. Officers of the Commonwealth Department of Workplace Relations and Small Business do not have these powers.
